articles.headline: Linking Public Works to Local Hiring Faces a Trump Challenge
articles.snippet: The administration is reviewing an Obama initiative allowing cities and states to force infrastructure projects to give preference to their residents.
articles.abstract: The administration is reviewing an Obama initiative allowing cities and states to force infrastructure projects to give preference to their residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Chicago Transit Authority chose a Chinese joint venture to build the city a new fleet of rail cars for $1.3 billion, the manufacturer’s vow to construct an assembly plant on the Southeast Side helped tilt the scale in its favor.

articles.headline: Fewer Immigrants Mean More Jobs? Not So, Economists Say
articles.snippet: Highly educated immigrants are good for the economy, but so are less skilled workers, economists say.
articles.abstract: Highly educated immigrants are good for the economy, but so are less skilled workers, economists say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the federal government banned the use of farmworkers from Mexico in 1964, California’s tomato growers did not enlist Americans to harvest the fragile crop. They replaced the lost workers with tomato-picking machines.

articles.headline: Even After the Glass Ceiling Yields, Female Executives Find Shaky Ground
articles.snippet: Sheri McCoy of Avon is the third prominent female chief executive to head toward the exit since June, making 2017 anything but the breakout era it was expected to be.
articles.abstract: Sheri McCoy of Avon is the third prominent female chief executive to head toward the exit since June, making 2017 anything but the breakout era it was expected to be.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the better part of five years as the chief executive of the cosmetics giant Avon Products, Sheri McCoy battled collapsing sales, a plunging stock price, a bribery scandal in China and the constant drumbeat of an attack from an activist investor.

articles.headline: John Kelly Quickly Moves to Impose Military Discipline on White House
articles.snippet: The former general and new chief of staff is seeking to quell dysfunction with a suddenness and force that have upended the West Wing.
articles.abstract: The former general and new chief of staff is seeking to quell dysfunction with a suddenness and force that have upended the West Wing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his six months as Homeland Security secretary, John F. Kelly often described the White House as one of the most dysfunctional organizations he had ever seen, complained to colleagues and allies about its meddling, incompetence and recklessness, and was once so angry he briefly considered quitting.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush, Michael D. Shear and Eileen Sullivan

articles.headline: Justice Dept., Under Siege From Trump, Plows Ahead With His Agenda
articles.snippet: Even as the department has been the subject of President Trump’s rage, Jeff Sessions and Rod J. Rosenstein are quietly and powerfully at work.
articles.abstract: Even as the department has been the subject of President Trump’s rage, Jeff Sessions and Rod J. Rosenstein are quietly and powerfully at work.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Jeff Sessions is at the Justice Department by 6:15 a.m., when he exercises on a treadmill near his fifth-floor office, showers in an adjoining bathroom, microwaves instant oatmeal and hand-washes the bowl, then prepares for a daily 8:20 a.m. meeting with his deputy, Rod J. Rosenstein.

articles.headline: Mexico’s Deadliest Town. Mexico’s Deadliest Year.
articles.snippet: Tecomán is a coastal town in Colima, where Mexicans once went to escape drug violence. Now it’s an emblem of the country’s soaring murder rate.
articles.abstract: Tecomán is a coastal town in Colima, where Mexicans once went to escape drug violence. Now it’s an emblem of the country’s soaring murder rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: TECOMÁN, Mexico — He slumped in a shabby white chair, his neck unnaturally twisted to the right. A cellphone rested inches away, as if he had just put it down. His unlaced shoes lay beneath outstretched legs, a morbid still life of what this town has become.

articles.headline: Jobs, Factories and Stocks Provide Economic Lift for Trump
articles.snippet: A payroll gain of 209,000 coincided with new auto investment and a stock market record, prompting the president to proclaim, “I have only just begun.”
articles.abstract: A payroll gain of 209,000 coincided with new auto investment and a stock market record, prompting the president to proclaim, “I have only just begun.”
articles.lead_paragraph: A stock market hitting record highs. Foreign corporations announcing big new plants in the United States. And robust hiring that has brought the unemployment rate to a 16-year low.

articles.headline: When Brokers Want to Move Your Money Out of a Very Good Thing
articles.snippet: Everyone should have a retirement plan as good as the Thrift Savings Plan that federal workers use. Here’s what happened when outside advisers tried to pry money loose.
articles.abstract: Everyone should have a retirement plan as good as the Thrift Savings Plan that federal workers use. Here’s what happened when outside advisers tried to pry money loose.
articles.lead_paragraph: So far this year, here’s what our friends in the federal government have done for — and to — citizens who hope to find simple ways to save enough money for retirement without anyone robbing them blind.

articles.headline: Opioid Users Are Filling Jails. Why Don’t Jails Treat Them?
articles.snippet: Getting methadone in jail gave a Connecticut heroin user a firmer foothold in recovery. But fewer than 1 percent of jails and prisons allow it.
articles.abstract: Getting methadone in jail gave a Connecticut heroin user a firmer foothold in recovery. But fewer than 1 percent of jails and prisons allow it.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — When Dave Mason left jail in October 2015 after his 14th criminal conviction, the odds were good that he would soon end up dead.

articles.headline: Toyota to Take 5 Percent Stake in Mazda and Build Joint U.S. Plant
articles.snippet: The factory’s location has not been decided, but the automakers said that it would most likely cost $1.6 billion and would employ about 4,000 workers.
articles.abstract: The factory’s location has not been decided, but the automakers said that it would most likely cost $1.6 billion and would employ about 4,000 workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Toyota said on Friday that it was taking a 5 percent stake in Mazda, another Japanese automaker, and that the companies would jointly build an assembly plant in the United States and would pool resources on new technologies.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Soble and Patricia Cohen

articles.headline: Leak Investigations Triple Under Trump, Sessions Says
articles.snippet: The attorney general vowed to bring criminal charges against those found to have given classified information to the news media.
articles.abstract: The attorney general vowed to bring criminal charges against those found to have given classified information to the news media.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced on Friday that the Justice Department is pursuing about three times as many leak investigations as were open at the end of the Obama era, a significant devotion of resources to hunt down disclosures that have plagued the Trump administration.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Eileen Sullivan
